awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2023 Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF award will provide partial support for the 2023 Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium (GPOTS), which will be held May 15-19, 2023 at The Ohio State University in Columbus, OH. More information about this conference may be found on the conference website at https://people.math.osu.edu/penneys.2/GPOTS2023.html.


GPOTS is the largest annual national conference in operator algebras and operator theory held in the United States. Since its beginning in 1981, it has grown into a major international conference with attendance approximately between 100-150 each year. Topics which will be featured at GPOTS 2023 include: C*-algebras, operator spaces, operator theory, non-commutative geometry, von Neumann algebras, and random matrix theory, with connections to many areas of mathematics, including ergodic theory, logic, and mathematical physics. Aside from plenary lectures, GPOTS 2023 will have contributed talks sessions primarily given by early career researchers, with many given by graduate students and postdocs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The 2023 Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium (GPOTS) was held at The Ohio State University May 15-19, 2023. 

Intellectual Merit: GPOTS is the largest annual operator algebra (OA) and operator theory (OT) conference in the United States. OA and OT are important and vibrant research areas with many connections to other areas of mathematics (including group theory, representation theory, and knot theory) and physics (inlcuding quantum field theory, condensed matter, and high energy).At GPOTS, participants have the chance to showcase and advertise their results, including both the plenary speakers and the participants who contribute talks at the contributed talks sessions. Since its inception in 1981, it has grown into a major international conference with attendance approximately between 100-150. 
The plenary speakers, affiliations at the time of the conference, and their talk titles are listed below:

Estelle Basor, American Institute of Mathematics - Some applications of Fredholm theory

Alexandru Chirvasitu, University at Buffalo - On the generic paucity of symmetries

Ben Hayes, University of Virginia - Applications of free entropy to the study of tracial von Neumann algebras

Fritz Gesztesy, Baylor University - Some recent developments in Hardy-type inequalities

Isaac Goldbring, UC Irvine - A nonstandard proof of the spectral theorem for unbounded self-adjoint operators

Srivatsav Kunnawalkam Elayavalli, UCLA IPAM - On the story of matrices of high finite order: Then (1942) and now (2022).

Marcelo Laca, University of Victoria - The right Toeplitz algebra of the ax+b semigroup of the natural numbers

Doron Lubinsky, Georgia Tech - Distribution of Eigenvalues of Toeplitz Matrices with Smooth Entries

Judith Packer, University of Colorado - Constructing spectral triples for noncommutative solenoids and bounded Bunce-Deddens algebras using length functions and inductive limits

Emily Peters, Loyola University Chicago - Categorifying connections

Sarah Reznikoff, Kansas State University - Notes on regular ideals of C*-algebras

Camila Sehnem, University of Waterloo - C*-envelopes of tensor algebras of product systems

Aaron Tikuisis, University of Ottawa - Classification of C*-algebras

Brett Wick, Washington University, St. Louis - Two Weight Inequalities for Calderón-Zygmund Operators

Guoliang Yu, Texas A&M - Index theory of the Dirac operator on manifolds with polyhedral boundary and its applications

Broader impacts: GPOTS emphasizes participation from early career researchers, especially graduate students and postdocs. In addition, participants have opportunities to network with other researchers and begin new collaborations. We were able to offer at least partial funding to each of the 121 people who registered, with priority for early career mathematicians. The conference had at least 100 participants, including 15 plenary speakers, 39 contributed talks, and many local participants. All contributed talks were accepted.


Last Modified: 08/28/2024
Modified by: David S Penneys
